title: James Cracknell admits he has always 'avoided things I won't be good at'
text:
He was the first celebrity to be booted off the 2019 series of Strictly Come Dancing.

But James Cracknell has looked back on his short stint on the BBC show with pride, insisting in a new interview that it's the bravest thing he's ever done.

The sportsman and his professional partner Luba Mushtuk were voted out of the competition after the first dance off, after failing to impress the judges with their jive.

Gave it his all: James Cracknell has looked back on his short stint on Strictly with pride, insisting in a new interview that it's the bravest thing he's ever done

Writing in his column for the Radio Times, double Olympic gold medalist James has admitted he's 'always avoided doing things that I know I won’t be any good at.'

'Being prepared to fail in front of millions of people has (strangely) been the bravest thing I’ve ever done.'

He explained that before Strictly dancing in front of anyone seemed impossible but Luba helped him shed his inhibitions in just a few weeks of training, by focusing on fun rather than steps.

Out: The sportsman and his professional partner Luba Mushtuk were voted out of the competition after the first dance off, after failing to impress the judges with their jive

'Strictly does funny things to your inhibitions and I’d promised Luba I’d give it everything I had,' he said of his second and final routine.

Unfortunately it wasn't enough for the judges, who voted unanimously to send him home over former footballer David James.

James admitted Craig Revel Horwood's critique is still ringing in his ears, but it's given him the perfect excuse to avoid the dancefloor in the future.

Low score: Writing in his column for the Radio Times, Double Olympic gold medalist James has admitted he's 'always avoided doing things that I know I won’t be any good at'

Hit the dance floor: He explained that before Strictly dancing in front of anyone seemed impossible but Luba helped him shed his inhibitions in just a few weeks of training

'I’ve learnt a huge amount about myself over the past five weeks. As for the future, if I’m ever asked to dance and don’t fancy it, I have proof from Craig Revel Horwood that I actually can’t dance,' he pointed out.

During an interview on Lorraine after his departure, James joked that Craig told him he only gave him points for 'putting his dancing shoes on', which led him to feel that he 'shouldn't have bothered'.

Talking about his exit from the show, he confessed: 'I spoke to Craig actually before the first show. He said "you get two points for putting your shoes on" and then he gave me two points! I was like I may as well have not bothered dancing.'

Never again: James admitted Craig Revel Horwood's critique is still ringing in his ears, but it's given him the perfect excuse to avoid the dancefloor in the future

However James went on to deny that he is a 'bad loser' following reports that he had to be 'calmed down backstage' following his elimination from the show.

He said: 'I could see someone getting annoyed if they were top of the leader board and then got voted off, whereas going into it being the bottom of the leader board you are pretty sure you are going to be in the mix at the bottom.

'[I was] not surprised and I can cope with being a bad dancer, that's not a surprise.

'But right through everything, I did in sport as well, being a bad loser is something I never have been.'
